title: Boutique Candy Retailer Sugarfina Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Minority backers include U2 singer Bono and Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon, court papers say. Sugarfina Inc., a chain of high-end candy shops whose backers include Bono and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Chief Executive David Solomon, has filed for bankruptcy.

title: Kamala Harris's Team Huddles to Plot Path Forward
summary: The Californian's advisers and donors are trying to figure out how she can move up in the 2020 field. Top advisers to Sen. Kamala Harris made their case to major donors behind closed doors in two meetings in New York on Friday, telling them they were working on defining the California Democrat with a more refined core message.

title: Prison at Low End of Guidelines Urged for Parents in College Scheme
summary: New court filing seeks jail time, not home confinement, and details lies by some parents who pleaded guilty. BOSTON-Federal prosecutors are recommending prison time for parents who have pleaded guilty in the college-admissions cheating case, urging the judge to send a message about privilege and fairness when deciding sentences.

title: India Loses Contact with Probe Just as It Prepares to Land on Moon
summary: Indian Space Research Organization monitor showed an image of the lander veering away from its expected path just before touchdown. NEW DELHI-India may have failed at its attempt to land a probe on the moon, losing communication with the lunar lander just as it was about to touch down.

title: In the Bahamas, Days of Desperation After Dorian's Destruction
summary: Resume Subscription. HIGH ROCK, The Bahamas-Pedro Baillou, 37 years old, spent more than a day in a mango tree in this small town on Grand Bahama Island. The water had risen so high there was no way to move on the ground.

title: Baseball Weighs Drug Policy Changes After Pitcher's Autopsy
summary: Tyler Skaggs had oxycodone, fentanyl and alcohol in his system when he was found dead. Major League Baseball and its players' union expect to discuss changes to the sport's drug program after an autopsy report revealed that Los Angeles Angels pitcher Tyler Skaggs had oxycodone, fentanyl and alcohol in his system when he was found dead on July 1.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Gain After Hiring Slows in August
summary: The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note falls to 1.555%. U.S. government bond prices rose after the Labor Department said the economy added fewer jobs than expected last month, raising new concerns about slowing growth.

title: The Trade Uncertainty Principle
summary: New evidence that tariff shocks have put economic gains at risk.. President Trump tweeted Friday that "The Economy is great. The only thing adding to 'uncertainty' is the Fake News!" Sorry, sir. The economy is fair to good, but it's no longer as great as it was last year, and a major reason is the uncertainty caused by Mr. Trump's trade policy.

title: Long Live the Incandescent Bulb
summary: The Energy Department will now allow you to choose your lighting.. Good news, Americans. If you like old-fashioned incandescent light bulbs, you can keep buying them. The Energy Department on Wednesday extended the lifespan of incandescents, which the Obama Administration in its twilight sought to extinguish.

title: Death of a Dictator
summary: Admired on the left, Robert Mugabe led a thriving country to ruin.. Africa's postcolonial era produced many tyrants, but few as destructive as Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe. The perverse accomplishment of the dictator, who died Friday at age 95, was to make a thriving country impoverished, corrupt and oppressed.

title: Doubt, Faith and a Strange Grace in the Critical-Care Unit
summary: I managed to track down a dying man's reluctant health-care proxy. His gratitude surprised me.. 'Did you get the health-care proxy for Mr. Jay yet?" the social worker asked. Embarrassed, I shook my head. Mr. Jay had been in the critical-care unit for two days, and I'd failed to check this important box. "It's a matter of time before he codes," continued the social worker. "Who's going to tell you guys when to stop?"

title: CNN Climate Show Wasn't Just Boring
summary: Hint to green media: Voters might actually be more prone to act if told the truth instead of lies.. CNN's seven-hour climate town hall with the Democratic presidential candidates was the ratings bomb you expected, and no wonder since there was little debate. If it was unwatchable, though, it wasn't unwatchable enough for some. The Columbia Journalism Review's "public editor for CNN," Emily Tamkin, beforehand insisted that moderators should proceed "on the assumption that the climate is in crisis," and limit themselves to calling for action and faulting inaction.

title: Brazil Says Amazonian Development Will Help It
summary: Environment chief says opportunity will save rainforest from illegal logging and farming, as Europeans criticize Bolsonaro's stewardship. BRASÍLIA-Brazil's environment minister said economic development in the Amazon is the best way to protect the rainforest, accusing foreigners and his leftist predecessors of trying to turn the region into an untouchable sanctuary.

title: NOAA's Plan to Save the Whales Has Maine Lobstermen Boiling
summary: The giant mammals have moved on to Canada, but the feds are targeting a local industry anyway.. I spent part of my first summer as a former governor working at a coastal Maine restaurant. My customers included lobstermen, and a hot topic of conversation was the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's attempts to protect the shrinking North Atlantic right whale population. NOAA has ordered Maine to recommend a plan this month to reduce the number of whale deaths in its coastal waters. There's only one problem: No whale deaths due to entanglements or ship strikes have been recorded in Maine waters since 1998.

title: WeWork's List of Potential Conflicts Adds to Questions Ahead of IPO
summary: Shared-office company faces corporate governance concerns as skeptical investors appraise its business. Losses at WeWork's parent aren't the only concern mounting about the shared-office company as it prepares to go public. Some of its practices push the boundaries of traditional corporate governance, analysts and investors say.

title: Buyout Firms Seek to Acquire Symantec for More Than $16 Billion
summary: Private-equity firms Permira and Advent propose deal for cybersecurity company. Symantec Corp. has received interest from a pair of private-equity suitors seeking to buy the cybersecurity firm for more than $16 billion after it agreed to a sale of a big chunk of its business, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: DOJ Investigating Auto Makers Over California Emissions Agreement
summary: Government seeks to determine if Ford, Honda, BMW, VW violated competition law. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department has launched an antitrust investigation into four auto makers that forged a deal with California on vehicle-emissions standards, escalating the conflict between the Trump administration and Sacramento over environmental regulations.

title: Modest August Job Growth Shows Economy Expanding, but Slowly
summary: Employers added 130,000 nonfarm jobs, jobless rate held steady at 3.7%. U.S. employment grew only modestly in August, suggesting that a global economic slowdown isn't driving the U.S. into recession but has dented growth.

title: Ex-Starbucks CEO Schultz Abandons Potential 2020 Bid
summary: Billionaire writes in a letter to supporters that he still intends to devote fortune to fixing the nation's political system. WASHINGTON-Former Starbucks Chief Executive Howard Schultz abandoned his potential independent bid for president on Friday, citing fears among the public that such a candidacy might lead to the re-election of a "uniquely dangerous" president.

title: Dean Foods to Remain Standalone Business
summary: Dean, which is the biggest milk producer in the U.S., has been facing more competition. Dean Foods Co. , which had been considering strategic alternatives including a sale, said Friday its board has decided the company will continue operating independently.

summary: The S&P 500 increased about 1.8% for the week; here were some shares on the move due to news. Nvidia Corp.

title: Agency Would Raise Bar for Asylum Seekers' Work Permits
summary: Trump administration favors scrapping requirement for approval within 30 days of application. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration wants to make it harder for asylum seekers to receive work permits while they wait for their cases to be decided, a move that could deter some immigrants from entering the country illegally.

title: States to Launch Google, Facebook Antitrust Investigations
summary: Separate inquiries by coalitions of attorneys general buttress Washington's scrutiny of the tech giants. WASHINGTON-Top state law-enforcement officials from across the country are formally launching antitrust probes into Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google starting next week, further pressuring tech giants already under federal scrutiny over whether their online dominance stifles competition.

title: Can the Climate Cause Survive the Democratic Primaries?
summary: Candidates make it hard to take the issue seriously.. Conservatives have often suspected that radical environmentalism is simply a vehicle to expand government. Democratic presidential candidates seem eager to confirm it.

title: Fannie and Freddie Shares Slide on Reform Plan
summary: Some investors found the latest blueprint to be lacking in specifics. Investors in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac aren't cheering the Trump administration's new plan for privatizing the mortgage-finance giants.

summary: Carrier says dispute with its workers has caused over 1,200 delays, cancellations. A mechanic for American Airlines Group Inc. is accused of trying to sabotage a plane just before it was scheduled to carry 150 passengers from Miami to the Bahamas in July.

title: Madoff Investor Kingate Files for Bankruptcy in the U.S.
summary: Two British Virgin Islands funds that funneled money to Bernard Madoff say they hope to ward off possible litigation from Deutsche Bank AG. Two British Virgin Islands funds managed by Kingate Management Ltd. filed for bankruptcy in New York to protect a recent settlement with the trustee responsible for marshaling funds to repay victims of Bernard Madoff's Ponzi scheme.

title: U.S. Stocks Climb After Jobs Report
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell signals in speech rate cut likely at meeting this month. title: Big Tech's Hands-Off Era Is Over
summary: Amazon, Google and Facebook now have to be much more proactive about managing their platforms. But it will be costly.. Internet giants for years have had their cake and eaten it too. Now a bittersweet tab is coming. The question is, who pays?

title: Sneakers: The Ultimate Guide for Obsessives
summary: As athletic shoes morph and multiply-emerging as a pivotal business for both men's and women's fashion-we offer an extensive primer, including the threats to Nike's dominance and 5 game-changing technological innovations. What's the last pair of shoes you bought? Let me guess: sneakers. Maybe a pair of collectible, cartoonishly colored Nike s? Leather Common Projects lace-ups in minimalist, office-friendly white? Or some humbly ho-hum navy-blue wool Allbirds? You weren't alone. The sneaker business hit $44 billion in sales last year in the U.S., up 9% from the year before, according to market-research firm the NPD Group.

title: Truckers Slashed Payrolls in August
summary: The job cuts in trucking came as hiring in manufacturing and other goods-producing sectors remained weak. Trucking fleets slashed 4,500 jobs last month and the pace of hiring slowed across the logistics field amid signs of tepid growth in the U.S. goods-producing economy.

title: Trump Administration Asks to Delay Release of 9/11-Related Documents

WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Friday asked for more time to decide whether to shield documents concerning allegations of official Saudi involvement in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, a sign that top Justice Department officials are struggling how to handle demands from victims' families to release the information.

title: Powell Signals Rate Cut Likely at Meeting This Month
summary: Fed chairman says U.S. economy remains in "good place," due partly to Fed easing. summary: While 181 CEOs say they are committed to serving 'all stakeholders,' when it comes to assessing their own performance, there is really only one master.

title: Russia's Opposition Looks Beyond Moscow for Election Gains
summary: Resume Subscription. MOSCOW-Targeted by police and barred from the ballot in Moscow's city elections, Russia's opposition is trying to gain a political foothold in other municipal races Sunday as it rides a rising wave of dissent against President Vladimir Putin.

title: Nucor to Replace CEO at Year-End
summary: Top U.S. steelmaker faces falling prices, slackening demand from manufacturers. Nucor Corp. said Chief Executive John Ferriola will retire at the end of the year and be replaced by veteran executive Leon Topalian, as the largest U.S. steelmaker navigates weakening demand from a decelerating industrial sector.

title: U.S. Tightens Cuba Sanctions, Stifling Dollar Flows
summary: U.S. would cap remittances to Cuban nationals at $1,000 a person per quarter, and prohibit them to Communist Party members and their families. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Treasury Department on Friday said it will curb remittances to Cuba and ban some money transfers through U.S.-regulated banks in a stiffening of a sanctions ban it says will further financially isolate the country.

title: Low Rates Spark Rally in S&P and Moody's Shares
summary: A surge in corporate-debt issuance means more business for rating agencies. Low interest rates have fueled a bonanza of corporate-debt issuance, and the rating agencies that stamp those bonds with seals of approval have enjoyed a boom of their own.

summary: Resume Subscription. When Barbara Marcus went to work in the world of children's books, many colleagues questioned her decision.

title: Afghan Leader, Criticizing U.S.-Taliban Deal, to Visit Washington
summary: Prospective trip by President Ghani represents government's latest effort to shape the draft withdrawal agreement. KABUL-Afghan President Ashraf Ghani is planning to travel to the U.S. for talks with President Trump, a senior Afghan official said, capping days of government criticism of a proposed U.S.-Taliban accord to withdraw U.S. and other foreign forces from Afghanistan.

title: James Mattis on Duty and Our Democracy
summary: The retired general is right about the need for allies, but they also need guns that are more than window dressing. Gen. James Mattis has done his country an important further service with his essay "Duty, Democracy and the Threat of Tribalism" (Review, Aug. 31). It is an encouraging insight into the values that animate not only him but the great majority of the men and women who serve the U.S. It also provides a timely warning against scorched-earth partisanship. I do, however, have two reservations.

title: Japan Is Not Keeping Agreement With Korea
summary: Korea has faithfully complied with the 1965 claims agreement with Japan and has no intention of breaking it.. Your editorial "Protectionist Diplomacy Goes Global" (Aug. 3) correctly describes the recent Japanese export-control measures against Korea as "retaliation." The Japanese government's argument in its Aug. 23 letter ("Japan Is Adhering to Its Treaty With Korea") rings hollow given Japan's shifting rationale.

title: Afghan Government Criticizes Proposed U.S.-Taliban Accord
summary: Officials say agreement, under which American and other foreign forces would withdraw, contains no penalties if insurgents fail to comply with deal. KABUL-The Afghan government is criticizing parts of a proposed U.S.-Taliban deal to withdraw U.S. and other foreign forces from Afghanistan, saying the accord contains no clear penalties if the insurgency fails to comply.

title: Let's Debate How Best to Measure Inflation
summary: The chained CPI-U was developed and published by the BLS and is a perfect example of the research Commissioner Beach praises.. U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Commissioner William Beach's response (Letters, Aug. 30) to our "Americans Are Richer Than We Think" (op-ed, Aug. 22) is instructive. He rightly notes that the Consumer-Price Index is widely used, that the BLS is impartial and transparent, that both measurement and operational errors are minimized, that the BLS conducts rigorous research and that many improvements have been made since 1978. We know all that because one of us was the assistant commissioner in charge of many of those improvements and even co-authored a paper in the Journal of the American Statistical Association with former Commissioner Janet Norwood analyzing them.

title: How to Have the Inheritance Talk With Older Parents
summary: Retirement columnist Glenn Ruffenach also answers questions on investing and Medicare. My parents are well into their 80s and have never discussed their estate/inheritance plan with me or my siblings. I'm not even sure if there is a plan. How can I broach this?

title: Sanders, Warren Vie for Supremacy in New Hampshire
summary: Vermont senator won the state with ease in 2016, but his fellow New Englander is mounting a strong bid for 2020. CLAREMONT, N.H.-Sen. Bernie Sanders, of nearby Vermont, won this state's Democratic presidential primary in 2016 and is eager for a repeat victory next year. But Sen. Elizabeth Warren, of neighboring Massachusetts, has zeroed in on the same turf, setting up a battle between the two liberal rivals over their shared backyard.

title: Securency's Former Manager Ordered to Pay Back Earnings From Alleged Bribery
summary: Peter Chapman, a former manager of Securency's Africa office, was ordered to pay about $545,000. A former employee of a currency note company entangled in foreign bribery allegations was ordered to pay back money made from alleged bribery in Africa, a U.K. agency prosecuting white-collar crime said Thursday.

title: CVS to Stop Planned Sales of Bankrupt uBiome's Explorer Test
summary: Stool-testing business touted partnership with drugstore chain as it filed for chapter 11. Drugstore chain operator CVS Health Corp. said it will stop shipments and halt sales of uBiome Inc.'s stool-testing kit a day after the medical laboratory service filed for bankruptcy while pointing to the retail partnership as a promising sign for its reorganization.

title: Don't Worry About the Job Market-Yet
summary: It makes sense for job growth to slow when unemployment is low, but global tensions and profit pressures loom. The job market is cooling, and that is probably no cause for alarm. Probably, but not definitely.

title: We Need the Shock of Dave Chappelle's Comedy
summary: He uses his stand-up routine to mock the pieties that define our popular culture. Dave Chappelle has become something of an unlikely hero to conservative critics of our tightly constrained and vigilantly policed popular discourse.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Gather at Site of Subway Station Attack
summary: Demonstrators demand release of surveillance footage from episode on Aug. 31. HONG KONG-Thousands of protesters gathered outside a subway station Friday evening where police beat people inside a train carriage last weekend, the first significant demonstration since the city's leader began offering conciliatory measures earlier this week.

title: The Onscreen Follies of a Homegrown Go-Getter
summary: Harold Lloyd, a contrast to contemporary stars like Chaplin and Keaton, stars in 'Safety Last!,' a paean to self-reliance.. In the 1920s, as silent-film comedy in America was reaching its pinnacle, sad sacks and stone faces dominated the screen. As the puckish but endearing Little Tramp, Charlie Chaplin embodied the plight and pluck of early 20th-century immigrants, while Buster Keaton-known everywhere as the "Great Stone Face"-personified the stolid stoicism of the little guy swept up in history.

title: Regulator Weighs Disclosing Names of Utilities That Violate Grid Security Rules
summary: FERC said if it releases names, it might hold back other details adversaries could use to target vulnerabilities. Regulators are weighing whether to disclose the identities of electric utilities that violate rules designed to protect the nation's grid against cyber and physical attacks.

title: How Many Mutual Funds Are Too Many?
summary: Some investors have so many, their portfolios become like index funds with hefty fees. It's the mantra among financial advisers: You need a diversified portfolio. To that end, investors hear a lot about the minimum number of mutual funds and ETFs they need to get that diversification.

title: On a Bumpy Foreign Trip, Pence Stuck to a Diplomatic Script
summary: Vice president worked to deliver the administration's message amid chilly receptions and controversies. Vice President Mike Pence frequently found himself at the center of, or adjacent to, controversy during a European tour this week. But in contrast with his boss, who often stirs fresh drama abroad, the U.S.'s second-in-command stuck to a phlegmatic display of diplomacy.

title: AI Takes Center Court at U.S. Open
summary: Artificial-intelligence technology powers cybersecurity, media coverage and player monitoring at tennis tournament. NEW YORK-Ask any tennis fan at the U.S. Open about the tournament's most important recent tech development, and most will point to Arthur Ashe Stadium's retractable roof. Behind the scenes, however, artificial intelligence is promising to change the tournament more than all-weather play ever could.

title: China's Central Bank to Free Up $126 Billion for Lending
summary: People's Bank of China to reduce amount of reserves commercial banks are required to keep with it by half a percentage point. SHANGHAI-China added fuel to its economy on Friday, releasing billions of dollars to banks as authorities struggle to revive business sentiment in the face of a protracted trade battle with the U.S.

title: 'The Anarchy' Review: Corporate Warfare
summary: The East India Co. was the most successful and ruthless start-up in history, pioneering insider-trading scams, corporate-lobbying scandals-and the British Empire.. If ever you wanted to see the shape of the future, the best place would have been in Founders' Hall in the City of London on Sept. 24, 1599. There in this old merchants' hall (founders meant brassfounders, not founding fathers) were assembled more than 100 of the City's richest merchants and sea captains, all primed to subscribe large sums ranging from £100 to £3,000 for the greatest startup in history. Among those present were the unstoppable explorer William Baffin and the great colonial booster Richard Hakluyt. The company they were all there to promote was "to venter in the pretended voiage to ye East Indies and other Ilands and Cuntries thereabouts to make trade . . . by buying or bartering of suche goodes, wares, jewelles or merchaundize as those Ilands or Cuntries may yeld or afforthe . . . (the which . . . it maie please the Lorde to prosper)."

title: What's Really Going On at Area 51: Maybe the Biggest UFO Party on Earth
summary: Resume Subscription. RACHEL, Nev.-Glenn Kaminsky put up a booth at the recent Bigfoot Daze festival in Willow Creek, Calif., to promote an invasion of Area 51, or at least a party in the same desert neighborhood.

title: 'The Testaments' Review: Is There No Balm in Gilead?
summary: Margaret Atwood reclaims control of the world of her 'Handmaid's Tale.'. Nine years after Miguel de Cervantes's "Don Quixote" was published to enormous international success, a sequel appeared continuing the misadventures of the delusional knight errant. The problem was that this book was written by an imposter, a man known by the pen name Alonso Fernández de Avellaneda. Cervantes, who had been secretly working on a follow-up, was incensed, and when he brought out the true second volume the following year, it contained numerous sneering references to Avellaneda's knockoff. In one chapter a character recounts visiting the gates of hell and watching devils use a copy as a tennis ball.

title: 'The Only Plane in the Sky' and 'Fall and Rise' Review: Out of the Blue on Sept. 11
summary: Two new journalistic accounts that strive to preserve the memory of Sept. 11, 2001.. A remembrance of beauty persists alongside the horrors that mark Sept. 11, 2001. A storm had swept across the Northeast the day before, giving rise that morning to a rare meteorological phenomenon known as "severe clear."

title: Five Best: Owen Matthews on Stalin's Great Terror
summary: The author of the forthcoming 'An Impeccable Spy: Richard Sorge, Stalin's Master Agent,' on books about Soviet tyranny.. By Ivan Chistyakov (2016)

title: Mysteries: Where Have They Taken the Billionaire's Wife?
summary: When a tech investor searches for his kidnapped spouse, he turns to her old flame for help.. 'This is nota regular case," says a police official of the kidnapping of Anastasia Christakos, an aid worker abducted while in Italy at the start of Henry Porter's compelling "White Hot Silence" (Mysterious Press, 439 pages, $26). Law enforcement is baffled that there has been no ransom demand, despite the fact that the victim's husband, California-based tech investor Denis Hisami, is a billionaire.

title: 'Gertrude Stein Has Arrived' Review: She Came Saw Conquered
summary: Gertrude Stein, American modernism's 'maiden aunt,' returned to the U.S. after an absence of 30 years a 'real lion.'. More peoplE have likely read aboutGertrude Stein than have actually finished one of her books. Stein's prose, with its reiterative cadences and distinctive mingling of the straightforward and the complicated, requires a certain acclimation before it is possible to go too far, and some readers never sign on to the journey. But Stein herself was the sort of character around whom legends will form: As in the cases of Ernest Hemingway, Sylvia Plath and Dorothy Parker, Stein's life makes an engrossing story in itself, and the books about her continue to proliferate.

title: Science Fiction: The Thing That Strangled Planet Earth
summary: In David Koepp's new nerve-shredder, bioweapons experts are called in to fight a fast-spreading mutant fungus.. In Oregon's Malheur National Forest, there's a giant, tree-killing mass of fungus that covers 3 square miles. It's 8,000 years old, it's genocidal to other plant life, and it's slowly spreading. Why haven't organisms like the Honey Fungus taken over the planet, strangling plant roots and turning the atmosphere to poison gas? Lack of nutrients is one reason, and adverse climate another. But what if it were to mutate?

title: Children's Books: A Crocodile Goes to Carnevale
summary: In a sequel to Fred Marcellino's 1999 'I, Crocodile,' the Egyptian river-dweller, having escaped Napoleon's clutches, decides to try the canals of Venice during Carnevale. In 1999, Fred Marcellino introduced children to the sly, mordant narrator of "I, Crocodile," a picture book about a gluttonous Egyptian river-dweller who is kidnapped by Napoleon Bonaparte and brought to Paris to wow the multitudes. As Marcellino (1939-2001) was finishing the book, he had to begin treatment for cancer. Unfortunately, the disease took his life before he could finish work on the sequel.

title: 'Passionate Spirit' Review: Songs in the Key of Me
summary: Wife and lover to artists, musicians and poets, Alma Mahler proclaimed herself a muse to genius and a composer in her own right.. On the second page of "Passionate Spirit," the English biographer Cate Haste runs up her flag: "I like Alma Mahler," she declares. This statement places the author in direct contradiction to three famous husbands, numerous lovers and most of Alma's acquaintance. A femme fatale who proclaimed herself a muse to genius, Alma Mahler aroused lust in her youth and gossip-seekers into her 80s. But not many people who knew her liked her very much, or for very long. I clearly remember her daughter, Anna Mahler, telling me that at no time in her long life did her mother ever have a devoted female friend.

title: 'Proof!' Review: Rulers and Compasses
summary: Clean lines and geometric shapes have been used as emblems of power from Versailles to Washington, D.C.. It is often said that the most influential book in the history of Western thought is Euclid's mathematical treatise "Elements." The work of a Greek mathematician living in Alexandria around the year 300 B.C., it redefined the way people thought about space and, eventually, everything else. The earlier civilizations of the ancient Near East had conceived of mathematics in terms of measurement, the conceptual starting point of their science being units of magnitude, like the hour or the foot. In the logical system of the "Elements," however, the basic ideas, what philosophers call the "primitive notions," weren't units of magnitude but intuitive concepts like point or line, posited in an abstract mental space. If one also granted the truth of a small number of apparently obvious postulates, which Euclid called "axioms" and "common notions," one could demonstrate the truth of a vast range of propositions.

title: Taking a Page From Tesla's Electric Playbook
summary: A giant electric vehicle doesn't quite produce something for nothing, but it reminds us of Elon Musk's claims that his company can. Move over Tesla ... way, way over.

title: Joshua, Ruiz Defend Decision to Stage Rematch in Saudi Arabia
summary: The heavyweight championship bout in December comes as the kingdom faces international scrutiny on issues related to human rights and gender equality. Andy Ruiz Jr. shocked the boxing world when he stopped Anthony Joshua in the seventh round to win the heavyweight title at New York's Madison Square Garden in June.

title: When Corporations Changed Their Social Role-and Upended Our Politics
summary: Large companies once offered workers lifetime security and generous benefits. Then they stopped, setting the stage for our populist moment.. Presidential elections in the U.S. are traditionally about economics. Next year's vote, and others around the world, have the feeling, however, of being not just about how the economy is performing in the moment but about something more fundamental: the economic system. What drove the rise of Donald Trump and politicians like him elsewhere was the promise that a new government with new policies could restore a fondly remembered (by some) economic and social order from the past. Those politicians' opponents on the left have a similar interest, though with completely different specifics, in remaking the political economy. It seems like centuries ago, though it was actually only four or five election cycles, when immediate economic conditions were a political issue but not the basic design of the economy.

title: Knowing If You Can Stomach the Next Big Market Swing
summary: That quiz your financial adviser gave you isn't really a good way of understanding your tolerance for risk. If I ask you in a questionnaire whether you are afraid of snakes, you might say no. If I throw a live snake in your lap and then ask if you're afraid of snakes, you'll probably say yes-if you ever talk to me again.

While the sport has evolved dramatically over the decades, most matchups are still played on Sundays. And come Monday, die-hard fans eagerly dissect every play and on-field move.

title: Hans Rausing Built Fortune on Long-Life Milk and Juice Cartons

The world now consumes more than 500 million Tetra Pak containers a day.

summary: Despite Maseratis' sexy exteriors and the boost from getting name-checked in this summer's hottest song, 'Old Town Road,' sales are understandably in free fall, says Dan Neil. So gather close, all those who need cheering, and revel in the glorious humanity that is "Old Town Road."

summary: Esper urges burden-sharing to fund U.S. facilities abroad. title: Don't Embarrass the Queen: U.K.'s Constitution Undergoes Brexit Stress Test

title: The Secret of a Charter School's Success? Parents
summary: Low-income families 'self-select' for Success Academy's demanding program, with remarkable results. Charter schools are a boutique phenomenon in American education, educating a mere 6% of U.S. school children. But they attract a disproportionate amount of attention-and controversy-because of their unique place in our education ecosystem. Public, tuition-free schools open to all students, but operated independently of school districts, they offer a Rorschach test revealing how one feels about U.S. public education at large. They can be perceived either as engines of innovation and an indispensable means to rescue children from failing neighborhood schools, or as an existential threat draining away resources-both money and engaged families-from traditional public schools.

title: A Painter Goes to the Opera
summary: Edgar Degas found inspiration in the singers, dancers and audiences of Paris. Among the impressionist painters who emerged in the 1860s, Edgar Degas (1834-1917) was an outlier in his unquenchable desire to represent modern urban life. Racecourses, laundry shops, brothels and the circus all fueled his imagination. But it was the Paris Opera, especially its ballet, which kept him coming back time and again. The appeal of modern ballet for Degas, who started out as a history painter, was to be found in its classical roots. When Degas's American patron Louisine Havemeyer asked him why he made so many ballet paintings, he replied: "Because, Madame, it's all that is left us of the combined movements of the Greeks."

title: In Reversal, Shanghai Disneyland to Allow Outside Food

Primack had just left his position of five years as a director of Design Miami, and Weissenberg, a former telenovela producer who also worked with Rick Owens on his furniture, had recently received a master's in design studies from Harvard. The couple got to work on their new gallery-cum-incubator, AGO Projects, which debuts this fall.
